description: On 16 July, the Ministry of Health issued a circular note on the reopening of borders, specifying the health protocols for passengers. Travellers coming to Djibouti by air/sea/land must be screened for COVID-19 upon arrival at ports of entry.  In addition, travellers coming to Djibouti must be equipped with protective masks at the time of departure or arrival at the points of entry, respect the physical distance of one meter, if possible, at all stages of the journey and carry a hydro-alcoholic gel throughout the trip. Upon arrival at Ambouli International Airport, all passengers are tested for COVID-19 using a minimally invasive saliva test. Travellers identified with the virus either go into isolation and treatment or depart Djibouti on the next flight without leaving the airport. Some destinations beyond Djibouti require a negative COVID-19 test certificate for entry.  The only facility in Djibouti offering these tests is Bouffard Hospital, charging $30 per test. Airlines may require passengers heading to these destinations to show a negative COVID-19 test certificate before allowing them to board their flight.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

The requirements for entry have not yet been finalised. Travellers are advised to confirm entry requirements before booking travel.

description: Land borders reopen. As of Dec. 16, authorities in Djibouti continue to maintain limited international travel and domestic business restrictions relating to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic. Land borders have reopened, including the crossings at Loyada, Galile, Galafi, and Balho, as well as international rail services at Djibouti City's Nagad Train Station. International rail services between Djibouti and Addis Ababa remain restricted to freight shipments only. Ambouli International Airport (JIB) remains operational for air transport, including commercial passenger travel; the ports of Tadjourah and Obock are open for maritime travel.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: All travelers must present a negative COVID test certificate within 72 hours of boarding any flight bound for Djibouti and not more than 120 hours prior to their arrival in Djibouti; all travelers will be screened upon arrival and must have a negative result in order to enter. description:
The Government of Djibouti has imposed a general, country-wide lockdown, except for essential services.  Traffic has been restricted to a minimum and is only allowed with government authorization.  On April 15, Djiboutian President Ismail Omar Guelleh issued a presidential decree extending the country-wide lock down for another 15 days, until April 30, but it is expected to last longer.  All passenger movement into and out of Djibouti has been suspended and ground, sea, and air borders are closed to passenger traffic. The Djiboutian Ministry of Foreign Affairs has also restricted military and humanitarian flights with personnel. 

 On April 17, the number of laboratory-confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Djibouti reached 732.  The Djiboutian authorities continue to systematically identify and test contacts through active tracing.  The Djiboutian Ministry of Health confirmed the first fatality of COVID-19 on April 9.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Event: On April 30, 2020 the Government of Djibouti extended the countrywide lockdown through at least May 8, 2020 and the Prime Minister announced a massive campaign to test for COVID-19, stating medical teams will be deploying throughout the country to test as many individuals as possible.

Passenger flights into and out of Djibouti remain suspended. The U.S. government does not anticipate arranging further repatriation flights from Djibouti at this time.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Ministry of Health of Djibouti has activated a national coordination mechanism on the 15th of March. This collaboration includes, the government, the ministry of heath, national institution of public health, IOM, WHO, WFP, UNHCR and the UNRC. The coordination platform is chaired by the Secretary General of the Ministry of Health. The platform has several sub-groups working on medical assistance, capacity building, surveillance and communication. In addition, the IOM is conducting from the 25th of March a Population Density Mapping exercise. This will guide public health interventions focusing on the ongoing COVID-19 threats. Several locations have been identified for the PMM, in coordination with national authorities.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Mandatory quarantine for travelers. Those who arrived in Djibouti in the past 14 days will be tested for COVID-19 and will stay home for a period of 14 days. Passengers displaying symptoms linked to coronavirus will be transferred to a nearby isolation facility while further tests are carried out and, if found to be positive, placed in a treatment facility which has been recently established. Enhanced screening at ports of entry. The Government of Djibouti has also introduced new measures at Djibouti-Ambouli International Airport to monitor coronavirus. Anyone arriving in Djibouti-Mabouli International Airport will have their temperature measured and passport checks for recent travel to affected areas.

description:
The government of Djibouti has adopted the decree 2020-049 / PR / MTRA of April 29, 2020 relating to the conditions for granting the compensatory allowance to employees and the allowance to companies during the pandemic. 
The adoption of this measure allows employees, placed in partial activity, to receive from their employer compensation to compensate for the loss of remuneration due to the hours not worked.
Thus, this proposal allows employees to receive compensation to compensate their wages up to 70% of gross wages. This compensation is funded at 30% of the gross remuneration of the employee placed in partial employment by the State. The remaining 40% by the employer to allow companies to avoid layoffs and retain their skills and employees to keep their jobs.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description: A presidential decree in Djibouti issues on May 10 announced the reopening of entertainment stores and businesses starting May 17. entertainment stores and businesses include household items and tools hardware stores, bazaars and other stalls, ready-to-wear stores, sewing workshops, appliance stores, libraries, stationery, hairdressing and beauty salons. These businesses have to install a hand washing device at the entrance of their establishment, organize social distancing with a limited number of clients, provide employees with necessary sanitary products, disinfect regularly the premises.
